Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I was able to build on basic statistical knowledge I gained in GLBL 121 to learn about OLS regression, omitted variable bias, analysis of variance tests, interaction terms, LPM, logit/probit, etc. I feel like I now have the ability to look at the methods section of a published paper and actually understand it, as well as question its validity/implications for public policy. I also continued expanding my knowledge in Stata.
A lot of statistics.

I developed a stronger understanding of how to understand and interpret data and statistics. This class focused mostly on how to interpret information, which I believe is very important. I had learned how to run many of the different tests and models that we learned about in this class, but I never really knew what they meant before.

Let's put it this way. Before I entered the AQA series, I would skip over the results section of any research paper. After this class, I specifically go looking for the results section so that I can find the places where the authors messed up or tried to cover up something from the readers. That is how much I've learnt in this class. We covered everything from p-values to fixed effects to homoskedasticity. Nothing makes sense in the beginning, and then it does. I left with enough confidence to provide policy recommendations based on results from a study.
Statistics
Research Analysis skills, STATA, applying statistics to policy
I learned about how to apply statistics in the real world, particularly when it comes to policy research.
Statistics
I learned general skills of analyzing data and basic regression models
Great overview of analysis skills, and easy to learn
Practical data analysis/useful research skills
Great buildup off 121
I learned very important skills for evaluating research, mainly many forms of regression analysis.
Lots of regression analysis
I learned a very solid amount about statistic analysis in a way I think will be incredibly helpful to me in future projects.
Learned high level statistical analysis

Learning more about how to use STATA --> omitted variable bias, linear regression, multivariate regression, fixed effects, anova, significance tests, etc. (THIS CLASS WAS ONLY FOR GLOBAL MAJORS IN SPRING 2019)
Fantastic class. Continuation of 121.
Basics of data analysis for social science research: omitted variable bias, multivariate regression, binary choice models, interaction, fixed effects, etc. Used Stata to implement.
Learned how to use Stata more and became more familiar with mulitvariate statistics.

My ability to evaluate and conduct statistical analysis was vastly improved in this course. I not only became more confident interpreting complex regression output but I further honed my abilities using Stata. I left this course feeling confident in my skillset for being a conscientious consumer and producer of research and with a passion to continue my academic investigation of this discipline.
I learned a lot about how to use Stata and about statistics

I learned to tangibly use Stata to accomplish and analyze most basic forms of regression. The goal, however, seems to be to prepare you to be a consumer of research rather than an actual researcher, and there could be a lot of improvement in the way problem sets are structured.
How to actually interpret different statistical models: simple multivariate regression, categorical predictors, logistic/probit regression, ANOVA, etc.
A lot of really cool regression and applied stats techniques + more info to build on some of the things I did in S&DS 230
I learned higher order techniques to analyse and interpret data.
I learned about practical research methods and statistics concepts.
I definitely have better grasps on stats concepts, as well as a fundamental grasp on the Stata program.

If you take GLBL 121, then GLBL 122 is a must-take. During the first month, we used our 121 knowledge to learn multi-variable regressions and their accompanying regression tables. I am not joking when I say that after this point, I began seeing regression tables everywhere-- in my Political Science courses, science courses, random articles, etc. The stuff you learn in this class is so, so applicable and even though some of it can be tricky and complicated, the learning is facilitated by 1) JT and his willingness to answer even the silliest of questions and 2) knowing that all of this will pay off in the future.
I learned more advanced statistics, analysis, and Stata.

JT is literally the strength of this course. I am terrified of math/statistics, but he has a particular skill at taking complex statistical knowledge and breaking it down so that students not only understand it, but understand it fully. He never moves through material too quickly and makes himself readily open to sitting down with students 1-on-1 in office hours, and is the kindest professor I have ever had/probably will ever have. The material is straightforward, makes sense, and is actually applicable. 

I do wish that problem sets would've been returned more immediately so that we could learn from past mistakes, I've done the last 3 psets without knowing if I got similar questions wrong throughout all 3. Having that feedback would've been really helpful.
For a statistics course, it's pretty good.

I really enjoyed how although this class was a lecture, there was a lot of interaction between the students and Professor Thomas. Professor Thomas kept the class interesting and explained the concepts very well.
This course is as interesting as a statistics class can be. The in-class lectures provide everything you need to do the psets and to do well on the exams.
The Problem sets could be dealt out earlier

Weaknesses: JT needs to be a bit more organized in terms of posting things when he says he will, being more available to meet with students, being a bit more clear of what will be on exams. Also, grading just needs to be done faster on problem sets and the grade scale needs to be available for everything!

Strengths: JT is awesome.

The strengths were everything.
The only weakness was that I felt like we often fell behind in the material and then just never ended up catching up. Given how important the material is, I thought it would've been really helpful if we could've actually gone through all of it (i.e. actually making the make-up lectures into lectures instead of review sessions).
Could be better organized with continuity between section and lecture

A huge weakness of this course is that to incentivize students to attend class, JT wouldnt post answers to questions on slides. However he wouldnt say no and give clear answers so I often felt like I never knew the exact analysis to give on Psets or exams. And grading would be harsh if you didnt answer a pset question correctly
Could have learned more material, and had a makeup lecture that for missed course, but JT makes material so accesible
A little disorganized as it being the first time JT taught the course. But overall engaging and useful
JT  was very unorganized this semester and the students felt the impact at times

Some of the expectations of the course were not well explained, but this was probably because it was the first time it was taught. This could be improved by making office hours schedule clearer, standardizing the problem set schedule, and making sure all students receive their work back before the final exam. This would allow students to identify mistakes earlier before repeating them.
Overall wonderful course. I think more practice problems and more clear feedback on the problem sets would be ideal.

Great engaging lectures. JT does a great job of getting students to buy in and really cares about us. Because it was the first year this course was taught, it felt at times like the class was in limbo and we didnt know exactly where we were going.

Strengths: teaches you more about STATA and what things to consider in terms of running regressions.
Things to be improved: not much theory/math/etc. you will learn what you need to do when using this for a job, but you won't really know the math behind why you do it (unlike in GLBL 121)

Strengths: well taught, important info
Weaknesses: very disorganized at times probably because it was the first time it was taught

Strengths: Emphasizes interpretation aspects of data, Professor Thomas makes sure to allow for plenty of questions, and the use of Stata.
Weaknesses: Papers over some of the math a little too much sometimes, class can move slowly at times, and the TA's are terrible graders. No context for deductions, just comments on points deducted without any clue as to the correct answer.

Strengths: Pacing of course is flexible (if a lot of people don't understand a certain topic, we will spend more time on it), great professor, great TAs, awesome class

Weakness: pset grade turnaround can be a bit slow

A strength of this course was definitely Professor Thomas, who helped break down the complex ideas to fairly intelligible fundamental concepts. Without his help I definitely could have gotten lost in the weeds especially towards the end of the semester. Additionally, I greatly appreciated the focus on policy-relevant issues which helped to make the class resonate with me to a greater extent than if we had merely discussed the theories and principles in the abstract. One area for improvement would be regarding feedback, especially on problem sets. This. was often delayed and meant that I sometimes would repeat mistakes without knowing because I had not received comments by the time the next problem set was due.
JT is a really good lecturer but I wish there was more feedback from the TFs. We did not get our pset grades back for a while so it was hard to know how we were doing

Great class! As usual, JT is a gem as a teacher and a person. The TFs were bad this semester though. It seemed like they didn't really understand what was going on -- at times they would answer questions incorrectly or in ways that contradicted lecture. Their sections were all but useless. Their grading was about what a robot given the answer key would do.

JT cares a lot and makes you feel incredibly comfortable asking any question you might have. However, this was the first time the course was offered, and he was clearly figuring a lot of it out as we went along -- there were only a total of six psets in the course and they were almost never posted when he announced they would be, and even with only six psets the content began to feel extremely repetitive (expect to interpret the coefficients in regression output over and over and over again). The grading is also weak -- critiques on psets are never incredibly clear, and it is hard to get ahold of JT and TA's outside of class/section to clarify why points were taken off.

Wished we had gotten through more material. There was a lot of exciting material on the syllabus that we didn't end up getting to, and I wish the course was paced better o that we would have been able to get to that material. Wished we had gotten more clear feedback -- problem sets and exams were returned very late, making it difficult to prepare for subsequent exams and assignments. I greatly dislike Stata, although I doubt that Jackson would change that.

The midterm was very long. Final was less long/more manageable. My biggest issue with the exams in general is that I feel like I'm memorizing answers instead of understanding information at times. Like I can regurgitate an interpretation and pros/cons of a specific method but might not actually understand the reasoning behind why that's the interpretation or why that's a good or bad thing (or how that good or bad thing came to be). Not sure how to fix it, but on exams and PSETs, there were many times when questions would be phrased like "should we be skeptical of..." and my gut reaction would be "yeah, probably" and then come up with reasons why (when in reality, I probably wouldn't blink an eye at these things, because I'm still trying to process the why's behind the what's that JT teaches)

Overall, though, taught well by an amazing/hilarious professor! It's my second time with him, and each semester has been a blast!

Professor Thomas is the strength of this course. He is a brilliant professor and ensures that everyone has understood the material well. His tests are very fair. The only weakness of this course was that it was a bit disorganised and problem sets were not returned on time (but this is understandable given that this was the first time the class was being taught to Yale College students).

It was not very well organized, and I did not feel like I was being given all the resources to learn the material properly until the last week of the course. I wish we were given back pset grades and comments sooner, as this made improving on future psets more difficult.

This was the first year this course was taught, so a lack of foundation and structure made it pretty weak. Professor Thomas knows a lot about the material and is usually a great teacher, but I can tell he did not quite know how much to teach or provide this semester.

The strength of this course is JT himself. While any stats professor can teach you this material, JT really brings it to life and finds ways in which to make it applicable to the realm of Global Affairs.

Professor Thomas is the best part of the class because he is such a good lecturer. I feel like I learned a lot, but I didn't perform well on the exams, and I never found out why because the feedback was absent or unclear. Also, please don't put the class from 11:35-12:50 again. It was so hard to focus because all I could think about was lunch. I actually think I might have performed significantly better if it were at literally any other time!

Yes! JT is an amazing professor, and his teaching style is really accessible. He also tells fun stories before each class, and is one of my favorite professors of all time. Even if you're not interested in math/statistics, this class really helps you build on that knowledge while not being too difficult, and has policy implications that are helpful if you're interested in going into government fields.
Yeah, JT is worth it.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Thomas was great and made the material, which at times could have been dry, interesting to learn. I learned how to interpret data, not just how to model it.
I would recommend this class to another student. Its a great way to learn statistics in an environment that is conducive to non-stem majors.
Yes
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Unfortunately, only Global Affairs majors can take the class/have to take the class. But I really think it's great nonetheless.
Major requirement!
Yes, it would Ben better to get feedback on our psets earlier, but JT is great and makes the class enjoyable
Yes
I would definitely recommend this to another student but because of how it fits in the global curriculum, most people are going to take it because they have to.
Yes. Love Professor Thomas and the class is honestly pretty interesting and useful
I think you can only take it if you're a global major, and if you're a global major, you have to take it.
Yes. Youll feel very employable.

I guess you have to take it if you're a global major, so you don't really have a choice. If you took 121, you should be used to some of the expectations. Some people came in from other classes, so that did make things a little more difficult at times.
Yes, great class with a great professor and you learn a lot
Great class! Take it to get to know JT and because the material is among the most useful you could learn at Yale.
It's a requirement for Global majors. Don't take it otherwise -- there are better places to learn stats.
Yes, wholeheartedly! Even if you think you know a lot of Statistics, this course will teach you how to actually interpret the models you create.

If you're taking it, it's probably for the Global Affairs major, and if it is, yes, definitely. Good applied stats course. Even though many things are phrased in the sense of "consulting" or something similar, the content is very good in a practical sense, and JT will explain how.
Only if they are in the major and cant get this practical material elsewhere.
Maybe by the spring of 2021, this course will be structured. Based off of what I just took, however, the structure is too messy to take.
YES!
Yes, but only if you have a strong interest in statistics or need to for Global Affairs.
